Geocoding

Source: vignettes/geocoding.Rmd
geocoding.Rmd

The AOI package provides an interface to the Open Street Map Nominatim API. This service does not require an API key and can be used for most research grade purposes. This page walks through a few examples of AOI geocoding:

Basic Geocoding

By Place Name

Basic geocoding functionality converts a place name into a lat/long coordinate pair.

geocode("UCSB")
request lat lon
UCSB 34.41459 -119.8458

By zip code (USA)

The AOI package provides basic geocoding by USA zip code by connecting with Tom Boutells archive of zipcode centroids.

geocode(zipcode = "80906
zip city state lat lon timezone dst
80906 Colorado Springs CO 38.79124 -104.8249 -7 1

By Event (beta)

Sometimes we want to geocode something that happen but that isn’t a set place that would appear in the OSM gazetteer. In these case AOI offers a beta tool to geocode by scrapping Wikipedia.

x = lapply(c("Deepwater Horizion", 
             "JFK Assasination", 
             "I have a dream speech"),
           geocode_wiki)

do.call(rbind, x)
request lat lon
Deepwater+Horizion 28.73814 -88.36594
JFK+Assasination 32.77903 -96.80867
I+have+a+dream+speech 38.88928 -77.05014

Reverse Geocoding

The oppisite of forward geocodeing is reverse geocodeing (going from lat/lon to place name). AOI offeres a reverse geocoding service that integrates results from ESRIs and OSMs APIs.

revgeocode(c(37, -119))
place_id 352144
osm_type node
osm_id 150949694
lat 36.9693904
lon -119.0173346
display_name Sawmill Flat, Fresno County, California, USA
hamlet Sawmill Flat
county Fresno County
state California
country USA
bb -119.0573346,-118.9773346,36.9293904,37.0093904
match_addr 93664, Shaver Lake, California
longlabel 93664, Shaver Lake, CA, USA
shortlabel 93664
addr_type Postal
city Shaver Lake
lon.1 -119
lat.1 37
wkid 4326

Geocoding Extensions

As a tool to support spatial research, AOI offers the abilty to geocode() multiple entries at a time and return spatial representations of the results:

Geocode Multiple Entries

geocode(c("UCSB", "Goleta", "State Street, Santa Barbara"))
request lat lon
UCSB 34.41459 -119.8458
Goleta 34.43583 -119.8276
State Street, Santa Barbara 34.41364 -119.6928

Return Points

do.call("rbind",
        lapply(c("UCSB", "Goleta", "State Street, Santa Barbara"), 
               function(x) geocode(x, pt= T)) ) %>% check(returnMap = T)

Return Bounding Box

Setting bb = TRUE will return the OSM defined bounding box of the queried place name:


geocode("Garden of the Gods", bb = T) %>% 
  check(returnMap = T)

Return all

If you want the coordinate, point, and bounding box realizations of a query, set all=TRUE


call = geocode(location = c("Garden of the Gods", "Quail Lake, Colorado"), all = T) 

str(call, max.level = 1)
#> List of 3
#>  $ coords:'data.frame':  2 obs. of  3 variables:
#>  $ pt    :Classes 'sf' and 'data.frame': 2 obs. of  2 variables:
#>   ..- attr(*, "sf_column")= chr "geometry"
#>   ..- attr(*, "agr")= Factor w/ 3 levels "constant","aggregate",..: NA
#>   .. ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "request"
#>  $ bb    :Classes 'sf' and 'data.frame': 1 obs. of  1 variable:
#>   ..- attr(*, "sf_column")= chr "geometry"
#>   ..- attr(*, "agr")= Factor w/ 3 levels "constant","aggregate",..: 
#>   .. ..- attr(*, "names")= chr(0)

check(call, returnMap = T)

Turn on full return

By default geocoding returns only provides the lat/lon coordinates from the queried location. To recieve all information about a query, set full = TRUE

geocode("Goleta", full= TRUE)
1
request Goleta
place_id 199031272
osm_type relation
osm_id 7080036
boundingbox c(“34.4137607”, “34.45877”, “-119.921877”, “-119.8050064”)
lat 34.4358295
lon -119.8276389
display_name Goleta, Santa Barbara County, California, USA
class boundary
type administrative
importance 0.545487227980481
